0.00.text: G'day viewers, my name's Graeme Stevenson, and I'd like to invite you to come on a

4.00.text: journey of creativity and learning and adventure through the series Colour In Your Life.

8.00.text: There's an artist in every family throughout the world.

12.00.text: Lots of times there's an artist deep down inside all of us as well.

16.00.text: So grab your kids, your brothers, your sisters, your aunties, uncles,

20.00.text: and mums and dads and come and see how some of the best artists do what they do.

36.00.text: (Graeme) Well hi folks, and welcome back to Colour In Your Life. Well we are in Hollywood, in

40.00.text: California today, and we are at the studio of a Mr Rob

44.00.text: Prior. Rob,  (Rob) How you doing, man? (Graeme) welcome to the show. This is fantastic

48.00.text: (Rob) Pleased to be here. (Graeme) This man here, as far as I can see and

52.00.text: everybody else I think in this country, is the Rock n Roll star

56.00.text: of art in the United States is the best way to possibly describe what Rob does.

60.00.text: He actually works with some of the leading rock bands in America and also

64.00.text: the leading Hip Hop groups as well Tech N9ne,  (Rob) Yep. (Graeme) for a start.

68.00.text: Tech's (Rob) My dearest friends. (Graeme) a really good friend of yours isn't he? (Rob) Yeah, he's cool. (Graeme) and one of the leading

72.00.text: Hip Hop people in the world. Linkin Park, what are some of the other groups as well?

76.00.text: (Rob) Flo Rida, Zakk Wylde, Chi Town,

80.00.text: there's so many - I mean, Jay Zee. (Graeme) Bruce Springsteen.

84.00.text: (Rob) Yeah. (Graeme) But when you see what Rob does, which is the incredible part, he

88.00.text: actually uses both of his hands to produce his work which is

92.00.text: really quiet amazing. And they are absolutely dynamically stunning

96.00.text: pieces is about the best way I can describe it. (Rob) Thank you. (Graeme) With

100.00.text: clients like George Lucas for a start, for the first time

104.00.text: I've actually got some notes with me because the man has done so much with his career

108.00.text: over a long, long time period of time. You've also worked with Marvel. (Rob) Marvel,

112.00.text: DC, (Graeme) Disney. (Rob) Disney, Dungeons and Dragons.

116.00.text: (Graeme) And you've put together video games as well. (Rob) I did, I worked on

120.00.text: Ghost Rider, Darkness, (Graeme) Is it Sporn you were

124.00.text: did some stuff with Spawn. (Rob) I did Spawn, Spawn the Impaler, I've done comic books.

128.00.text: I've worked with just about every comic company out there. (Graeme) That's amazing.

132.00.text: (Rob) I'm finishing up my last graphic novel that I will

136.00.text: ever do a full graphic novel called Blood Merchant, for Benaroya Pictures, (Graeme) Aha.

140.00.text: (Rob) Mike BetaRoya. (Graeme) So how did you come about wanting to use two hands?

144.00.text: (Rob) When I was ten years old, I was being trained to be an artist my whole life, my

148.00.text: family line are artists but none by profession. I thought the same

152.00.text: thing that every ten year old thinks - what if I used my right hand? (Graeme) Yeah. (Rob) No ten year old thinks that.

156.00.text: And so I switched, I switched my left hand

160.00.text: to be my dominate hand and I retaught myself how to write. I refused

164.00.text: for the next two years refused to make my right hand my dominate hand. (Graeme) Aha. (Rob) I learned to catch,

168.00.text: I play guitar, so I play guitar with both hands. (Graeme) Wow. (Rob) And

172.00.text: then one day, I was published pretty young, so I had

176.00.text: an international cover due, and math homework due

180.00.text: (Graeme) Yeah. (Rob) and I was like - I've got to go faster, so I picked up two brushes

184.00.text: and I was like oh I can do this. And then I realised that I could actually do my math homework and paint

188.00.text: (Graeme) Same time - I think the painting won out in the end didn't it? (Rob) You know at that

196.00.text: that was it. I often paint two paintings or three paintings, or

200.00.text: four paintings at one time. (Graeme) And we've actually got some footage of Rob working on

204.00.text: stage with Tech N9ne, and some of the other guys in the Hip Hop bands as well

208.00.text: which is really quite amazing. I mean what he does on the stage is really quite dynamic,

212.00.text: and he moves around all over the place - paints backwards, paints upside

216.00.text: down I think sometimes as well. But today, we're very privileged to

220.00.text: actually have two fantastic companies that are sponsoring the show.

224.00.text: Princeton Art Brushes, which is the largest manufacturer of art brushes in the United

228.00.text: States, I mean potentially the world. And also Royal Talens from

232.00.text: from the Netherlands, who makes a huge amount of products as well. I mean tell us something just

236.00.text: their products? (Rob) The thing about Princeton, is I use

240.00.text: I use a brush called Umbria, Umbria Catalyst. (Graeme) Yeah. (Rob) but the Umbria's my

244.00.text: my favourite because it just holds its

248.00.text: shape so well and I abuse the hell out of my brushes.

252.00.text: If you watch any clips or even see me today I'm just like -  beat the hell out of them.

256.00.text: And no other brush honestly, no

260.00.text: other brush can put up with that. I've never had a brush like,

264.00.text: then go back to form, you know, and not fall apart.

268.00.text: And with you know, Royal Talens, the colors are amazing. The

272.00.text: consistency of it is just perfect (Graeme) Yeah. (Rob) and they have different things like

276.00.text: inks. So I can't say good enough things about them, it's you know. (Graeme) It's amazing, a

280.00.text: huge amount of ranges as far as the products concerned: (Rob) Oh, absolutely. (Graeme) inks,

284.00.text: watercolors, acylics, oils - it's fantastic. But you're going to be using the

288.00.text: watercolor pencils today. (Rob) I'm using watercolor pencils and gouache. (Graeme) Okay. (Rob) I

292.00.text: might be using some ink. Half the time I don't know

296.00.text: what I'm gonna do. I mean if it's around me when I'm painting, I'll pick it up.

300.00.text: (Graeme) Yeah. (Rob) You know, if there's dirt there I'll probably use that, you know. (Graeme) Yeah, when you see

304.00.text: Rob work you'll understand what I'm talking about. He listens to music

308.00.text: continually, consistently. (Rob) I cannot paint without it. (Graeme)  Literally, if he's not listening to

312.00.text: music of some sort he actually stops like a robot. But he's gonna have

316.00.text: ear phones in, he's going to be listening to music and he's still gonna be able hear me talk

320.00.text: while he's doing what he's doing, but it's an essential part of your creativity. (Rob) Yes,

324.00.text: I know, and you guys come in and go: do you have to have music?

328.00.text: Ahh, well either that I could just stand there the whole time

331.83.text: (Graeme) Yeah. (Rob) so. (Graeme) Yeah, well when you see

336.00.text: you'll understand cause it's really quite amazing. But what I'm going to do is, I'm going to get out of here. I'm still going to ask you some questions

340.00.text: as we go along. (Rob) Sure. (Graeme) You're going to show us how you create these amazing pieces and

344.00.text: how you use these fantastic products at the same time. (Rob) Ah, yes. (Graeme) I'm looking forward top it.

364.00.text: Rob. Well you've got a pretty iconic gentleman up there. (Rob) Yes. (Graeme) One of the twenty

368.00.text: seven club. (Rob) Yes. (Graeme) You wouldn't have to guess I think, that's Jimmy Hendrix,

372.00.text: and you're very famous for painting very famous people.

376.00.text: And you've got some watercolor paper there, and you've got some

380.00.text: watercolor, Talen watercolor pencils. (Rob) Yep. (Graeme) And you're doing

384.00.text: doing what you do which is work in two hands. Tell me, tell me the process? (Rob) You know,

388.00.text: when I work in two hands, a lot of times I'll

392.00.text: what I'll do is one will hit a higher part,

396.00.text: or just a different color. (Graeme) Yeah. (Rob) I can figure out where I'm going to blend ahead

400.00.text: of time, so when I'm doing it that way I know

404.00.text: what one hand is doing one thing and blending it in, and the other is just

408.00.text: laying a base. (Graeme) But you also use, you use

412.00.text: Windex. (Rob) I do, Windex tends to chew

416.00.text: paint. It tends to, instead of water - water will move

420.00.text: a paint around, were Windex will eat the paint and make it drip.

424.00.text: Gravity then works with it better. So I make a line

428.00.text: like that, and I spray it with Windex

432.00.text: and you can watch it just eat the paint.

436.00.text: But if I take water, say if I go over here

440.00.text: it doesn't do anything. So the difference is

444.00.text: one will chew the paint through and the other will move the paint

448.00.text: around. So the other thing I'm doing is

452.00.text: I'm actually going to paint this with gouache, but I'm laying down

456.00.text: a little bit of a color base

460.00.text: with watercolor pencil, so I know that I can go in

464.00.text: and have a base laid down where my colors are actually

472.00.text: creating a map for myself. I use to be purely a

476.00.text: photo realist and then I, with the onset of Photoshop

480.00.text: up and all of that is like why, why would you do that? So

484.00.text: I also got to a point were I like mistakes;

488.00.text: I love mistakes, because mistakes are what brings life to a painting to

492.00.text: me. If I feel it's getting too perfect I'll do something really crazy and I'll

496.00.text: throw paint at it, or if anybody watches videos of me I'll spit paint,

504.00.text: Talens is a fantastic paint, but you're not suppose to eat it.

508.00.text: (Graeme) Yeah. Rob's actually listening to his music now so,

512.00.text: so he's actually listening to me and listening to the music. He actually responds

516.00.text: very dramatically to what the music doing, and he sort of gets into these zones

520.00.text: occasionally. He calls it blacking out, and he just starts to work

524.00.text: and music kicks in and away he goes. But one of my

528.00.text: heroes is a friend of yours, Neal deGrasse Tyson, and he

532.00.text: said: I'd like to get into your brain. (Rob) Yeah, he is a

536.00.text: god, he's a trip. I was at San Diego

540.00.text: Comic-Con, and I was on stage with him and listening

544.00.text: to his theories on Star Wars, and Lightsabers and

548.00.text: stuff is hilarious. (Graeme) Yeah. (Rob) It's hilarious. (Graeme) You do like

552.00.text: about sixteen comic conventions a year. (Rob) I can't make it to all of them, but

556.00.text: I try and hit a lot of main ones. (Graeme) I can see what you mean about getting

560.00.text: those Princeton brushes a workout. (Rob) Oh, that is an

568.00.text: while that next comment was really going to be: I do things with these brushes nobody should

572.00.text: do. (Graeme) I can just see now this Rock n Roll

580.00.text: has to be. (Rob) It's true. (Graeme) That's great but.

588.00.text: is quite extraordinary, what Rob achieves with

592.00.text: two hands and two brushes is just quite amazing, it really is.

596.00.text: We're very privileged to be here.

600.00.text: Looking at your earlier work, you were really

604.00.text: disciplined as far as the reality of the technique (Rob) Yes. (Graeme) is concerned.

608.00.text: And then it was your wife, Bev (Rob) It was. (Graeme) who basically

612.00.text: said let your hair down, so to speak. (Rob) Yeah, this is how I've painted pretty much

616.00.text: my whole life in my studio, and I was getting

624.00.text: needed to have something that was gonna challenge me a

628.00.text: bit more. And my wife came to me and she said why don't you paint for

632.00.text: everybody like you paint in your studio. And I was like, nobody wants

636.00.text: to see that. And that's kinda how it started, I mean this is

640.00.text: how I've personally always painted for myself. (Graeme) Yeah.

648.00.text: is much smarter than I am,

652.00.text: knew enough to say, you know what,

656.00.text: don't, don't  quite art because if you quite art its like

660.00.text: quitting breathing, you know after you've done it for so

664.00.text: long it's just ingrained in you - it's what you know.

672.00.text: I switched over to this crazy whacked out style that I

676.00.text: have. (Graeme) You've actually done a few album covers for Tech

680.00.text: N9ne. (Rob) Tech N9ne, I've done album covers for Blue Oyster

684.00.text: Cult, wow, a tonne of people. (Graeme) Those Tech N9ne images but

688.00.text: are just fantastic, (Rob) Oh, thank you so much. (Graeme) like another

692.00.text: world. (Rob) Thank you so much. Yeah, well you know, it's funny cause

696.00.text: in meeting Tech, I had talked to a Producer who said

700.00.text: you really need to meet Tech. It would be great if you guys worked

704.00.text: together. You know, me being me, I was like I don't know, maybe.

708.00.text: Let me meet him, let me see if it's even gonna work. (Graeme) Yeah.

716.00.text: Bob's Big Boy in Toluca Lake, (Graeme) Okay. (Rob) and ah,

720.00.text: he came in and he just started talking about his ideas

724.00.text: and we just hit it off. (Graeme) Amazing, and you've become good friends since.

728.00.text: (Rob) Oh yeah, yeah,Tech is - he's great. But he probably fills

732.00.text: four or five shows a year with him now. He's really the person that

736.00.text: kinda got me to go on stage. I'd been talking about it

740.00.text: with one of the other owners of Strange Music, Travis O'Guin, and

744.00.text: I was like - no, I don't know, maybe, maybe not.

748.00.text: No. And then Tech came to me he's like well don't worry about it cause

752.00.text: I have terrible stage fright and

760.00.text: and you know, he goes don't worry the lights will be in your eyes. And I was like, oh, okay,

764.00.text: so I walk out on stage and - he

768.00.text: lied. (Graeme) I can see everybody. (Rob) You know, it's like

772.00.text: wait a minute. And so I'm on stage

776.00.text: and I'm thinking to myself I can't - I can't do this. He's

780.00.text: my friend, I can apologise to him. I can't

784.00.text: do this after all. And I turned around - and my wife will disagree with me,

788.00.text: she will say she was just standing there. Cause when I tell this story

792.00.text: you know, she's like - I didn't really do that. She did. (Graeme) Yeah.

796.00.text: (Rob) She was standing there with arms crossed,

800.00.text: so I was like, face my wife or face the crowd. Take the crowd.

804.00.text: (Graeme)  And actually we've got a picture of Bev, that you've painted as well

808.00.text: that we're just (Rob) Yes. (Graeme) screening up too. She's a beautiful woman. (Rob) Ah, thank

812.00.text: you, thank you very much. My wife's cool. (Graeme) So you were telling the

816.00.text: viewers a funny story about a mate of yours, and he said something about

820.00.text: a chicken head? What's the story with that? (Rob) So there

824.00.text: was a publisher, (Graeme) Yeah. (Rob) he's actually a friend, and he

828.00.text: called me up. He didn't know me at the time and he said Prior,

832.00.text: you know, I want to hire you to do my three book series but I

836.00.text: know you hide things in your paintings. So if you hide anything

840.00.text: I'm going to fire you. And I was like dude, what would I do

844.00.text: hide a chicken head in every page? So I did.

852.00.text: when I got to the second issue, I did a double splat

856.00.text: page, which is two pages that open up into a long

860.00.text: painting. And if you turn the entire book sideways,

864.00.text: its a giant chicken head and

868.00.text: so, on the third issue he calls me up and he goes, you know I'd fire you right now

872.00.text: but I'm too busy looking for your chicken heads. And there

876.00.text: for it stuck. And had I known that a chicken head

880.00.text: would be what stuck with my fan base, I'd have picked something way cooler

884.00.text: than a chicken head. (Graeme) You've also done some amazing pieces

888.00.text: of the series Game of Thrones, There's some very spectacular series out there

892.00.text: these days, and we are in the centre of Hollywood. One of a gentleman

896.00.text: called John Snow, well he's one of the characters in

900.00.text: the actual (Rob) Yeah, it's one of my favourite shows

904.00.text: on the air as well. So you know,

908.00.text: painting, painting it and getting to put a little bit of

912.00.text: of my spin on them: I love it. (Graeme) And even

916.00.text: a lot of the Star Wars characters that you've done, I mean I can

920.00.text: almost guarantee that somebody's watching this show has actually seen your work somewhere,

924.00.text: somehow, either on a book, or an album cover, or somewhere

928.00.text: cause I know I'd seen it many years ago myself. Star Wars, with - you did one of all the

932.00.text: villains. The Sith Lords. (Rob) Oh yeah. (Graeme)  that's pretty cool. I have come here today

936.00.text: Rob, to tell you I'm your father. (Rob) Wow.

940.00.text: That's not weird. (Graeme) So you were

948.00.text: So not only are you a famous artist yourself, but you

952.00.text: actually know some other very, very famous artists (Rob) Oh, (Graeme) as well.

956.00.text: (Rob) Yeah, I know a lot of artists that are

960.00.text: just amazing and Dorian Vallejo, is just

964.00.text: he's just an amazing artist. You know, to me it's a very

968.00.text: cool little tight community once you

972.00.text: get in there. Art as with any arts at all,

976.00.text: music, acting, whatever it is, can sometimes get

980.00.text: petty and that's a shame because I think every, I think art

984.00.text: should all just stick together and you know, should all

988.00.text: be - I'm not saying one giant happy family cause that's never gonna happen,

992.00.text: but I do think that there needs to be more

996.00.text: trading secrets and more talking and all of that. There's so much

1000.00.text: to learn from so many people there's just not enough time in the

1004.00.text: world for it. (Graeme) Who would you say influenced

1008.00.text: you in your career? (Rob) Well, my Dad,

1012.00.text: who is an amazing artist, really

1016.00.text: influenced me. There's an artist named Bob Heindel, who is

1020.00.text: who when he was with us

1024.00.text: was known as the modern day Gar. And Drew Struzan,

1028.00.text: another, another big influence you know,

1032.00.text: growing up, cause he did so many of the iconic movie

1036.00.text: posters. (Graeme) Yeah, and even some of the work you've done yourself

1040.00.text: sort of harks back to the bygone era of movies with

1044.00.text: Boris Karloff, (Rob) Oh. (Graeme) and you know, Nosferatu the

1048.00.text: original vampire movie. I love old, old monster movies.

1052.00.text: And by the way, Graeme I have to say

1060.00.text: I'll fire it right back at you: when did you start?

1064.00.text: (Graeme) A long time ago - five years of age.

1068.00.text: But you must have started about the same age yourself didn't you? (Rob) Yeah, I was

1072.00.text: like basically out f the womb hen my parents were having me

1076.00.text: do art. But you know just because you or I

1080.00.text: started so young, doesn't mean that you have to be young

1084.00.text: to start, cause you don't. You can start at any age

1088.00.text: and accomplish whatever you want to accomplish. (Graeme) So in

1092.00.text: comparison with the gouache, obviously the inks give you

1096.00.text: a lot more flow with your color. (Rob) The one thing I

1100.00.text: really like about the Ecoline Inks,

1104.00.text: is the fact that they're so bright

1108.00.text: and they really just pop. (Graeme) You were saying before

1112.00.text: one of the concerts you did with Tech N9ne, that you

1116.00.text: had a business man from Saudi Arabia walk up to you

1120.00.text: at the end of one of the shows. (Rob) Yeah, and he brought,

1124.00.text: he bought a painting from me which I won't say the price, but I will say

1128.00.text: it set, it set the standard for my pricing today.

1136.00.text: this: thank you! You know, sometimes artists just need

1140.00.text: one or two really lucky breaks (Graeme) Yeah.

1144.00.text: (Rob) to, to happen to them. But you know,

1148.00.text: really at the end of the day, and I wish I would have come up with this saying

1152.00.text: but I did not, I just am

1156.00.text: repeating it. Luck is just preparation meets

1160.00.text: opportunity. It really is preparation; it is

1164.00.text: knowing your craft and knowing it well.

1216.00.text: (Rob) So I think now this painting is missing one thing.

1220.00.text: (Graeme) What's that? (Rob) That is you coming over here

1228.00.text: So if you wouldn't mind stepping in here. (Graeme) What do you want me to do?

1232.00.text: (Rob) You can do one of two things - I'm going to let you pick. You can start doing

1236.00.text: some of this with these little white specks. (Graeme) Little white doddley dads. (Rob) Or you can get in

1240.00.text: here and just do a little bit of tweaking on that. (Graeme) I'll do this on the side here. (Rob) Done!

1248.00.text: Okay, I'll grab some of these Princeton brushes,

1252.00.text: pretty cool. I don't, I'm sort of

1256.00.text: trying to look at what Rob's doing so that I don't

1260.00.text: destroy any of the continuity that he's got.

1264.00.text: (Rob) Continuity - anyone out there watching this, please

1268.00.text: drink your beer and laugh at that statement. There is no true continuity

1272.00.text: because it's all just fun. (Graeme) Instead of the Three Amigos,

1276.00.text: it's the Two Amigos. (Rob) It's the Two Amigos. Woohoo!

1300.00.text: (Rob) Do it. Do it. (Graeme) That looks really cool.

1304.00.text: (Rob) You know, I am missing one thing. (Graeme) What would that be?

1312.00.text: (Rob) A chicken head (Graeme) Okay. (Rob) right there.

1316.00.text: (Graeme) God, look at it.  (Rob) And ah,

1324.00.text: Fantastic buddy. That is brilliant - absolutely brilliant. (Rob) Thank

1328.00.text: you for having me on your show, man. (Graeme) Okay guys, what an amazing

1332.00.text: day with an incredibly talented man. You are the Super Star

1336.00.text: that everyone makes you out to be - absolutely. (Rob) I don't know about that, but thank you, sir. (Graeme) This is an artist

1340.00.text: who's a Rock n Roll star in America - there's no two ways about it. But

1344.00.text: it's been fantastic, mate, your work is absolutely brilliant. Now if somebody wants to catch up with you

1348.00.text: and see what you're doing, your website is? (Rob) rob prior dot com, and

1352.00.text: you can see most of my things there. You can see I have somebody else updating it so they put

1356.00.text: all of my dates and stuff on there. And Instagram

1360.00.text: is: prior two art, p r i o r number two,

1364.00.text: art a r t, and that's Twitter and Instagram, and

1368.00.text: my Facebook is Rob Prior Official. (Graeme) Absolutely, come in and see a

1372.00.text: journey of an amazing talented human being, no two ways about it. Also, before we go,

1376.00.text: we obviously would love to thank Princeton Brushes and also Royal

1380.00.text: Talens for what they have done for Rob. They make some

1384.00.text: fantastic products. Come in and see us at colour in your life dot com dot au.

1388.00.text: And Rob, thank you so much for having us here today - it was hilarious.

1396.00.text: until we meet again: make sure you put some color in your life. We'll see you next time.
